Introduction

Secondary hypertension is defined as persistently elevated blood pressure resulting from an identifiable underlying anatomic or physiologic condition.  It accounts for 5%-10% of hypertension cases and contrasts with essential hypertension, in which no underlying cause is apparent.  Identifying and treating the underlying cause often can lead to improvement or resolution of hypertension.



Clinical features suggestive of secondary hypertension include the following:



  • Onset at an early age (<30)
  • Severe or resistant hypertension (ie, uncontrolled despite â‰¥3 antihypertensive agents)
  • Abrupt onset of hypertension in a previously normotensive individual
  • Evidence of end-organ damage at diagnosis
  • Prominent symptoms such as palpitations, headache, and sweating


Major causes of secondary hypertension include the following:



  • Renal parenchymal and renovascular disease:  chronic kidney disease (CKD), glomerulonephritis, and renal artery stenosis
  • Endocrine disorders:  thyroid disease, hyperaldosteronism, pheochromocytoma, and Cushing syndrome
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Medication-induced hypertension

Renal disease

Pathophysiology



Renal parenchymal and renovascular disease can cause hypertension due to volume overload, activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) (

figure 1
), and sympathetic nervous system stimulation.  CKD, glomerulonephritis, and renal artery stenosis are common etiologies.

Risk factors



  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Primary (essential) hypertension
  • Smoking
  • Obesity

Pathology



  • CKD:  loss of kidney function resulting in impaired excretion of sodium and water.
  • Glomerulonephritis:  inflammation of the glomeruli leading to proteinuria, hematuria, and reduced kidney function.
  • Renal artery stenosis:  narrowing of the renal arteries causing decreased renal perfusion and activation of RAAS.  Major causes include atherosclerosis (older age, male sex, smoking, atherosclerosis in other organs) and fibromuscular dysplasia (younger age, female sex).

Clinical presentation



  • CKD:  peripheral edema, anemia, and uremic symptoms (eg, nausea, vomiting)
  • Glomerulonephritis:  Hematuria (tea-colored urine), proteinuria, and edema
  • Renal artery stenosis:  Abdominal bruit, sudden-onset hypertension, recurrent flash pulmonary edema, and decline in renal function after ACE inhibitor or angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) therapy

Diagnosis



  • CKD:  elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and abnormal imaging (ultrasonography showing small, echogenic kidneys)
  • Glomerulonephritis:  urinalysis showing red blood cell casts, proteinuria, and serologic tests (eg, antinuclear antibodies, antiglomerular basement membrane antibodies)
  • Renal artery stenosis:  Doppler ultrasonography, MR angiography (MRA), or CT angiography (CTA)

Laboratory/imaging evaluation



  • Serum creatinine (and estimated glomerular filtration rate) and electrolytes
  • Urinalysis and urine albumin-creatinine ratio
  • Renal ultrasonography, MRA, CTA, or renal scintigraphy

Management



  • Control of hypertension with RAAS inhibitors (eg, ACE inhibitors, ARBs), diuretics, and calcium channel blockers
  • Treatment of underlying kidney disease (eg, immunosuppressive therapy for glomerulonephritis)
  • Revascularization procedures (angioplasty or stenting) for renal artery stenosis

Complications



  • End-stage renal disease
  • Persistent proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome

Endocrine disorders



This section will focus on the following endocrine causes of secondary hypertension:



  • Thyroid disorders
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Cushing syndrome

Thyroid disorders

Pathophysiology



Both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism are common causes of hypertension.  Hyperthyroidism increases cardiovascular sensitivity to circulating catecholamines, leading to increased heart rate and myocardial contractility with increased cardiac output.  This manifests as predominantly systolic hypertension with increased pulse pressure.  Conversely, hypothyroidism causes increased systemic vascular resistance and intravascular volume expansion, presenting as predominantly diastolic hypertension with decreased pulse pressure.

Clinical presentation



Characteristic features of hyperthyroidism include the following:



  • Hyperadrenergic symptoms (palpitation, sweating)
  • Heat intolerance
  • Weight loss
  • Lid lag (and proptosis in Graves' disease)
  • Diffuse goiter (Graves' disease) or nodular goiter (toxic nodular disease)


Characteristic features of hypothyroidism include the following:



  • Fatigue
  • Cold intolerance
  • Weight gain
  • Mild goiter may be present

Diagnosis



Initial testing should include serum TSH; thyroid hormone (eg, free thyroxine [T4]) can be performed as a reflex test or with later TSH retesting.  Further diagnostic testing should be considered as follows:



Primary hyperthyroidism (ie, elevated thyroid hormone levels, suppressed TSH):



  • Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin assay:  positive in Graves' disease
  • Radioactive iodine uptake scintigraphy:  shows diffusely increased uptake in Graves' disease, focally increased uptake in toxic nodular disease, and decreased uptake in destructive thyroiditis (release of preformed thyroid hormone)


Primary hypothyroidism (ie, low thyroid hormone levels, elevated TSH):



  • Antithyroid peroxidase antibody assay can support the diagnosis of chronic autoimmune (Hashimoto) thyroiditis (by far the most common cause) but is often unnecessary.

Treatment



Primary hyperthyroidism



  • Beta blocker reduces adrenergic features.
  • Definitive treatment options may include thionamide antithyroid drugs, radioiodine ablation, and surgical thyroidectomy.


Primary hypothyroidism



  • Levothyroxine replacement

Hyperaldosteronism

Pathophysiology



Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome) results from autonomous secretion of aldosterone (

figure 2
) from the zona glomerulosa (
figure 3
) of the adrenal cortex, leading to sodium retention, increased potassium excretion, and hypertension.  It can be due to a solitary adrenal adenoma or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia.

Risk factors



  • Family history of hyperaldosteronism
  • Age (common in young and middle-aged adults)
  • Female sex

Clinical presentation



Due to the effects of aldosterone, clinical presentation includes:



  • Hypertension, often resistant to treatment.
  • Hypokalemia:  Serum potassium may be normal at baseline, but severe hypokalemia can be triggered by diuretic therapy.
  • Mild hypernatremia may be present.
  • Metabolic alkalosis.


Peripheral edema may be mild or absent due to aldosterone escape (increased intravascular volume increases pressure natriuresis and atrial natriuretic peptide release, thereby limiting net sodium retention)

Diagnosis



  • Elevated plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) and suppressed plasma renin activity (PRA); PAC/PRA ratio >20

    • In contrast, elevated PAC and PRA with a PAC/PRA ratio ~10 suggests secondary hyperaldosteronism (eg, renovascular hypertension, cirrhosis, renin-secreting tumor)
  • Confirmatory tests (eg, saline infusion test, oral sodium loading test [showing absence of aldosterone suppression due to renin-independent aldosterone secretion])
  • Adrenal imaging (CT or MRI) to identify adenoma or hyperplasia

Management



  • Adenoma:  Surgical resection (adrenalectomy)
  • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia:  Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (eg, spironolactone, eplerenone)

Pheochromocytoma

Pathophysiology



Pheochromocytomas are catecholamine-secreting tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla or extraadrenal paraganglia (paraganglioma).  Excessive catecholamine (eg, epinephrine, norepinephrine) levels can lead to episodic or sustained hypertension.

Risk factors



  • Genetic syndromes (eg, multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ), Von Hippel-Lindau disease)
  • Family history of pheochromocytoma
  • Age (commonly presents in the third to fifth decades)

Clinical presentation



  • Episodic hypertension is classic, but sustained hypertension also occurs.
  • Paroxysms of headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis.
  • Tremor, pallor, and anxiety.
  • The classic triad (episodic headache, sweating, and tachycardia) is present in <50% of patients.

Diagnosis



  • Assessment of increased catecholamine production:  Plasma fractionated metanephrines or 24-hour urinary fractionated catecholamines and metanephrines (breakdown products of epinephrine and norepinephrine) (
    figure 4
    ).
  • If biochemical tests are abnormal, imaging (CT or MRI) is indicated to localize the tumor.
  • Nuclear scintigraphy (eg, metaiodobenzylguanidine [MIBG] scan) can be used to localize small tumors if CT or MRI is negative and is sometimes used to detect metastatic disease.

Management



  • Surgical resection (adrenalectomy) is curative, but induction of anesthesia and manipulation of the gland can trigger intraoperative hypertensive crisis due to sudden release of catecholamines.
  • To prevent this, patients should receive pharmacologic alpha-adrenergic blockade (eg, phenoxybenzamine) followed by beta-adrenergic blockade (eg, propranolol, metoprolol) prior to surgery.  Beta-blockers should never be initiated first because unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation can cause severe vasoconstriction and lead to a life-threatening hypertensive crisis.

Complications



  • Hypertensive crisis during surgery
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Metastatic disease

Cushing syndrome

Pathophysiology



Cushing syndrome results from excessive production of glucocorticoids, leading to sodium retention, increased vascular sensitivity to catecholamines, and activation of RAAS.  Major causes include the following:



  • Adrenal adenoma/carcinoma:  autonomous production of cortisol
  • Pituitary adenoma:  secretes ACTH, stimulating cortisol production (ie, Cushing disease).
  • Ectopic ACTH production:  paraneoplastic syndrome (eg, small cell lung cancer).

Clinical presentation



  • Central obesity, moon face, buffalo hump (
    figure 5
    )
  • Purple striae, easy bruising
  • Muscle weakness, osteoporosis
  • Glucose intolerance

Diagnosis



  • Hypercortisolism can be confirmed by finding elevated cortisol levels in a:

    • late-night salivary sample.
    • 24-hour urine collection.
    • low-dose dexamethasone suppression test:  Administration of a potent glucocorticoid rapidly suppresses ACTH and cortisol secretion in normal patients but not in patients with Cushing syndrome.
  • Once hypercortisolism is established, plasma ACTH level distinguishes an adrenal (ACTH suppressed/independent) or pituitary (ACTH elevated/dependent) etiology (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ).  ACTH stimulates conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone, which results in increased cortisol synthesis (zona fasciculata) and androgen production (zona reticularis); it also has a trophic effect on the zona fasciculata and reticularis, eventually leading to hyperplasia.
    • Low ACTH levels are seen with autonomous adrenal production of cortisol (eg, adrenal adenoma or carcinoma) or exogenous glucocorticoid exposure due to feedback suppression.
    • High ACTH levels occur with pituitary adenomas (ie, Cushing disease) or ectopic ACTH production by nonpituitary tumors, which can be further distinguished with the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test:
      • Pituitary sources of ACTH are only relatively resistant to feedback inhibition, and high doses of dexamethasone will suppress ACTH and cortisol levels.
      • Nonpituitary ectopic sources of ACTH (eg, small cell lung cancer) are completely resistant to feedback inhibition, and ACTH and cortisol will remain elevated following high doses of dexamethasone.
  • Adrenal CT or pituitary MRI is indicated based on results of biochemical testing.

Management



  • Surgical resection of adrenal or pituitary tumor
  • Medical management with steroidogenesis inhibitors (eg, ketoconazole, metyrapone)
  • Radiation therapy for pituitary adenomas

Complications



  • Osteoporosis and fractures
  • Diabetes mellitus

Cardiopulmonary disorders



This section will focus on the following cardiopulmonary causes of secondary hypertension:



  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Obstructive sleep apnea

Coarctation of the aorta

Pathophysiology



Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing of the aortic lumen, most commonly just distal to the left subclavian artery.  This leads to hypertension proximal to the coarctation with increased cardiac afterload, augmented by activation of the RAAS; pressure distal to the coarctation is proportionately lower.  The blood pressure gradient is determined by the severity of the constriction and degree of collateral circulation (

figure 6
).  Coarctation of the aorta is most often due to a congenital defect; depending on the degree of narrowing, it may present shortly after birth, in childhood, or in adulthood.

Risk factors



  • Congenital heart defects (eg, bicuspid aortic valve in ~40% of patients)
  • Genetic conditions (eg, ~3%-10% of patients with Turner syndrome)
  • Family history of coarctation of the aorta

Clinical presentation



  • Infantile coarctation of the aorta is typically characterized by severe stenosis of the aortic arch that presents as shock when the patent ductus arteriosus closes.
  • Children and adults who present in later life tend to have milder constriction and asymptomatic upper body hypertension.  Some patients can have headaches, epistaxis, lower extremity claudication, or symptoms of heart failure.
  • Hypertension in the upper extremities with lower blood pressure in the lower extremities and weak or delayed femoral pulses (brachiofemoral delay).
    • Differential of >10 mm Hg is abnormal and >20 mm Hg may indicate significant obstruction.
  • Classically associated with murmur best heard over the back or left infrascapular area but variable (no murmur, systolic murmur from flow across the narrowed aorta, murmur from coexisting cardiac anomalies).

Diagnosis



  • Echocardiography to visualize the coarctation and assess the gradient across the narrowed segment.
  • MRI or CT angiography for detailed anatomic assessment.
  • X-ray of the chest may show a "figure 3" sign and rib notching in older patients due to erosion of the undersurface of the ribs from intercostal collateral circulation but is not necessary in the diagnostic work-up (
    Coarctation of the aorta CXR
    ).

Management



  • Surgical repair (eg, end-to-end anastomosis, subclavian flap aortoplasty)
  • Balloon angioplasty with or without stenting in selected cases

Complications



  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Re-coarctation or aneurysm formation at the repair site
  • Aortic rupture or dissection

Obstructive sleep apnea

Pathophysiology



Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
) leads to intermittent hypoxia, sympathetic nervous system activation, and oxidative stress, contributing to the development of hypertension.

Risk factors



  • Obesity
  • Male sex
  • Age (middle-aged and older adults)
  • Neck circumference >17 inches in men, >16 inches in women

Pathology



  • Upper airway obstruction:  repeated collapse of the upper airway during sleep, causing apneic episodes and hypoxemia

Clinical presentation



  • Excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration
  • Loud snoring
  • Witnessed apneas
  • Morning headaches

Diagnosis



  • Standardized clinical assessments (eg, Epworth Sleepiness Scale, STOP-Bang questionnaire (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    )) can stratify risk and determine need for further testing.
  • Polysomnography (sleep study):  apneic episodes, oxygen desaturation, and arousals.

Management



  • Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy
  • Weight loss and lifestyle modifications
  • Oral appliances for mild to moderate OSA
  • Surgical options for refractory cases (eg, uvulopalatopharyngoplasty)

Complications



  • Resistant hypertension
  • Cardiovascular disease (eg, atrial fibrillation, heart failure)
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Medication-induced hypertension

Pathophysiology



Certain medications can induce hypertension by increasing sodium and water retention, enhancing sympathetic activity, or causing direct vasoconstriction.  Common causes include:



  • Oral contraceptives:  Estrogen increases angiotensinogen production.
  • Corticosteroids:  sodium retention and volume expansion.
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs:  Reduced prostaglandin synthesis leads to vasoconstriction.
  • Decongestants:  Sympathomimetic effects cause vasoconstriction.


In addition, some recreational drugs can cause hypertension.  The sympathomimetic effects of cocaine cause hypertension and tachycardia in a dose-dependent fashion.  Other drugs associated with hypertension include other stimulants (eg, amphetamines, 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine [MDMA or Ecstasy]), phencyclidine, and marijuana.

Management



  • Discontinuation or substitution of the offending medication.
  • Initiation of antihypertensive therapy considered if offending medication is necessary.
  • Close monitoring of blood pressure after medication changes.

Pediatric considerations

Renal disease



In children, secondary hypertension frequently results from congenital renal conditions (eg, polycystic kidney disease, renal dysplasia).  Diagnosis is typically made through renal ultrasonography.

Endocrine disorders



  • Pheochromocytoma can present in children in association with MEN2 syndrome.
  • Cushing syndrome may manifest as growth retardation and obesity along with hypertension.  Diagnosis is based on cortisol levels and imaging studies to identify the source of excess cortisol.

OSA



OSA is increasingly recognized in children with obesity or craniofacial abnormalities.  Management may include CPAP therapy, weight management, or adenotonsillectomy if indicated.

Medication-induced hypertension



Medications such as corticosteroids and stimulants can cause hypertension in children.

Coarctation of the aorta



Typically detected in infancy or early childhood, coarctation often shows differences in blood pressure between the upper and lower body.  Diagnosis is primarily through echocardiography, with early surgical intervention being crucial.

Summary



Secondary hypertension is defined as hypertension resulting from another identifiable medical condition.  Major causes include renal parenchymal and vascular disease, endocrine disorders (eg, thyroid disease, hyperaldosteronism, pheochromocytoma, Cushing syndrome), coarctation of the aorta, obstructive sleep apnea, and medication-induced hypertension.  Secondary hypertension should be suspected in patients with severe or resistant hypertension, hypertension with unusual symptoms (eg, palpitations, sweating, headache), abrupt onset of hypertension or onset at unusual age (eg, <30), or evidence of end-organ damage at the time of hypertension diagnosis.  Identifying and treating the causes of secondary hypertension often can correct the blood pressure elevation and reduce morbidity and mortality.
